import Mathlib

open Topology Filter Set Polynomial Function

abbrev putnam_1981_b5_solution : Prop := sorry
-- True
/--
Let $B(n)$ be the number of ones in the base two expression for the positive integer $n$. For example, $B(6)=B(110_2)=2$ and $B(15)=B(1111_2)=4$. Determine whether or not $\exp \left(\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{B(n)}{n(n+1)}\right)$ is a rational number. Here $\exp(x)$ denotes $e^x$.
-/
theorem putnam_1981_b5
(sumbits : List ℕ → ℤ)
(B : ℕ → ℤ)
(hsumbits : ∀ bits : List ℕ, sumbits bits = ∑ i : Fin bits.length, (bits[i] : ℤ))
(hB : ∀ n > 0, B n = sumbits (Nat.digits 2 n))
: (∃ q : ℚ, Real.exp (∑' n : Set.Ici 1, B n / ((n : ℝ) * ((n : ℝ) + 1))) = q) ↔ putnam_1981_b5_solution :=
sorry

```lean4
theorem putnam_1981_b5
(sumbits : List ℕ → ℤ)
(B : ℕ → ℤ)
(hsumbits : ∀ bits : List ℕ, sumbits bits = ∑ i : Fin bits.length, (bits[i] : ℤ))
(hB : ∀ n > 0, B n = sumbits (Nat.digits 2 n))
: (∃ q : ℚ, Real.exp (∑' n : Set.Ici 1, B n / ((n : ℝ) * ((n : ℝ) + 1))) = q) ↔ putnam_1981_b5_solution := by
  have h1 := hsumbits []
  have h2 := hsumbits [1]
  have h3 := hsumbits [0]
  have h4 := hsumbits [1, 1]
  have h5 := hsumbits [0, 1]
  have h6 := hsumbits [1, 0]
  have h7 := hsumbits [0, 0]
  have h8 := hB 1 (by norm_num)
  have h9 := hB 2 (by norm_num)
  have h10 := hB 3 (by norm_num)

  have h12 := hB 5 (by norm_num)

  have h14 := hB 7 (by norm_num)
  have h15 := hB 8 (by norm_num)

  have h₁₂ := hB 8 (by norm_num)
  have h₁₃ := hB 9 (by norm_num)
  have h₁₄ := hB 10 (by norm_num)
  norm_num at h₁ h₂ h₃ h₄ h₅ h₆ h₇ h₈ h₉ h₁₀ h₁₁ h₁₂ h₁₃ h₁₄
  <;>
  simp_all [Finset.sum_range_succ, Finset.sum_range_one, Nat.div_eq_of_lt]
  <;>
  norm_num
  <;>
  aesop
```
